utterances: But can you imagine why some politicians now are loath to take this on given what happened to Jimmy Carter in 1980 by Ronald Reagan, given the fact that this speech is often derided as a low mark in his presidency and something that maybe have cost him reelection.
Well, I've never frankly, I've never heard anybody say it may have caused him reelection.
Well one of the factors, one of the factors.
Generally speaking, if in the end you win the next election no matter what you did or didn't do up to that point you're considered a genius.
If you lose the next election, then nobody wants to be associated with you or just about anything that you did or stood for.
And if anything I think Democrats are in some ways more guilty of that than even Republicans are.

So if you were advising Barack Obama or John McCain right now to make this kind of speech and to urge Americans to conserve - a conservation speech, what would you, as a former press secretary, what would you say would be the best way to communicate that?
I wouldn't advise either one of them just to make just a conservation speech.

I would urge both of them to be very honest about the fact that there may not be in the short term, it may be more sacrifice than benefit but for our long term good and the long term benefit of our children and grandchildren this is what needs to be done.
I think Americans will respond to that.
Jody Powell, thanks very much.
Thank you.
That's Jody Powell, former press secretary for President Jimmy Carter in the 1970s.
Now here to give us another point of view, Todd Boyd.
He's a professor of critical studies at the University of Southern California's School of Cinematic Arts.
He specializes in the African-American community and pop culture.
Hi, Todd.
Hi.
So you just heard my conversation with Faye Williams from Enough is Enough, and her group is protesting what it calls demeaning images on BET and MTV.
Before we talk about that specifically, back up and give us a little context for these kinds of protests around content and image in the past.

Well, you know, certainly, since hip-hop culture has been visible in the mainstream, you know, the last 15 or 20 years, there have been a number of instances where people have objected to language, images, the nature of the culture itself.
You know, in the '90s, C.
Delores Tucker, William Bennett, people like this were going after hip-hop, Dionne Warwick.
You know, you could even go back to the '70s if you wanted to talk about the black exploitation era and people, you know, criticizing the images that were in those films.
You know, there's been a long, sort of back and forth around…
And…
…African-American images, and this is really just another example of the same sort of thing, that being certain people wanting to control content.
But there's nothing new about it.

Todd, there also have been protests that effectively changed law, I'm thinking of the PMRC, the Parents Music Resource Center, Tipper Gore and some of her associates actually changing the labeling laws basically around explicit lyrics.
This is something different.
This is an attempt to really speak to the executives and try to get them to change voluntarily.
Do those kind of protests generally work?
Well, I mean, you know, we're talking about these protests this morning on the national airwaves, so people are paying attention.
But do they ultimately work?
I think it depends on the instance and the context.
I don't see that this will work.
I mean, their complaints are very, very, very subjective.
When you talk about words, like decency and responsibility and positive and negative, these are very subjective terms and they change from person to person.
What you have are group of individuals who want to impose, you know, their standards on everyone else.
And there's a certain arrogance there, a certain, you know, lack of being connected with what's going on in the real world that I think is fueling them.
But ultimately, you know, the way to go about this is not by violating someone's privacy and trespassing and protesting in front of their home.
What measures then do people have if they want to try to influence a corporation that's putting out content that they find offensive?

Well, you know, I think it's important for all of us to recognize that as individuals, we have, you know, the opportunity to develop our own standards of what we consider right and wrong, good and evil, and otherwise.
But there's something known as tolerance.
You know, there are a lot of things that I don't necessarily like, but I'm not trying to deny them to people who do like them.
You know, the great thing about television, for instance, is if you don't want to watch something, there's nobody to force you to watch it.
You can turn it off, you can change the channel, there are other options.
You know, people often talk about obscenities which is sort of laughable because you mentioned PMRC records and labels.
So if you buy a CD and it's labeled, you're warned that there's a certain language on that.
So if you buy it and there's that language there, you should've known that beforehand.
You can't say these things on the radio, you can't say them on television.
There are already standards in place.
So I'm not always sure what they're talking about because, you know, there are restrictions in place.

But I think, you know, people get fed up with themselves and they think that they're more important than they really are and they want to challenge some of these issues, but I think they are really going about it the wrong way in overstating the case.
That was Jewell Parker Rhodes with a few lessons she learned growing up.
Rhodes shares more stories and grandmother's wisdom in her latest book, Porch Stories.
She's been dead for 30 years, but without her I wouldn't have the life that I have today.
She saved me.
She gave me my profession - telling stories - and she also gave me my values.
So, grandmother, this is a praise song to you.
And I feel your spirit every single day.
Tell me more about how you grew up and what role she played in your life.
My mother had abandoned the family, so grandmother raised me.
And she was instrumental in that she taught me that the world is a glorious place.
She taught me to embrace humanity.
And she'd say, there's never an excuse for joy.
And to be thankful.
And I think instead of being bitter or just being the hurt, wounded child because my mother wasn't around - instead she gave me the strength to be somebody.
And she also said, Jewell, educate yourself.
Dream big.
And when I was with Grandmother, after I had spent a time with my mother and father, they had tried to renegotiate their marriage.
But I finally had to leave home again and go to my grandmother's home.
And grandmother then took me down to Mellon Bank(ph), and Mellon Bank said, you know, well, you want to buy clothes for this girl, you want to send her to school?
Well, what's your collateral for a loan?
And my grandmother said, she's my collateral.
And this loan officer said, hmm, a smart girl.
That's very good.
So we got $500.
I started Allegheny Community College, and my grandmother took me to Lerner's to get me my winter coat.
So she really just was so instrumental and changed my life.
I also had a grandmother - I still have her.
Even though she's passed away, I feel very close to her.
And I even did a little segment about her and with her voice here on NPR.
What do you think it is that sometimes allows grandmothers to impart wisdom in ways that parents can't?
I think it's always natural for children to rebel against their parents and establish their own identity.
And also, I think parents get invested in, you know, doing the right thing?
And so their anxiety about being good parents might in a way affect a relationship negatively.
A grandparent can be simply affirming.
A grandparent has been there, done that child-raising stuff and has the wisdom of experience.
And so in some ways, they're free to love without the anxiety of being the actual parents.
They're free to give.
And I think children are so desperate for love and so desperate for the embrace - so having a grandparent, an elder, an aunt, to say yes to them is really what they need in order to be whole.
What did your grandmother Ernestine look like, smell like, sound like?
Ooh, grandmother - they actually say I look like Grandmother Ernestine.
She was taller, though, and I, of course, thought she was gorgeous.

I don't think I'm gorgeous, but my grandmother, to me, she was special because of her smile - special because of her glimmer in her eyes, and she always smelled of a combination of starch - from when she was doing the laundry.
Remember when you would boil starch, Argo starch?
And she would smell of chicken, and she would smell of cinnamon spices and nutmeg.
So she cooked and she cleaned and she had this way of holding you and just snuggling you up against her bosom that made you just feel as though I could stay here forever.
If you had to pick one lesson that she taught that is the sort of cornerstone of your life, what would it be?
That the world is a joyful place, all of us are mixed-blood stew and prejudice is sinful.
So when I go out into the world crossing cultures, ethnicities, I know that I am related to everybody.
The whole world is filled with my family.
And I think in a way when bad things happen, when I do experience discrimination or when life gets tough, my fundamental belief is that all blood bleeds red and we are all one.
So there's no bitterness.
Grandmother really taught me how to keep love at the corner of my existence, and that has saved me over and over again.

You know, you have written so many fiction and nonfiction books -Voodoo Dreams, Magic City, Douglass' Women, ""The African-American Guide to Writing and Publishing Non-Fiction."" You say that your grandmother taught you to be a storyteller.
What do you mean by that?
Well, on the porch she would tell stories.
She never said, you know, Jewell, you know, do such and such.
Instead, she would tell me a long story.
So, for example, about love.
She'd tell me about Mr. and Mrs. Abby.
Everybody thought they were poor and life was tough and Mr. Abby, when he died, was leaving Mrs. Abby alone.
And what the community didn't know is that the two of them were so rich because they had such a great love for one another.
So then from that story I would know, well, how do you know how a man loves you?
By the little things, by the care and that the love from a man might be the most important thing.
The love from your family is the most important thing.
Not what you buy, not what you have.
So she didn't say that.
She told me the story, and I deduced that.
And so that's what I do in my fiction.
So in Douglass' Women, there actually is a line: how do I know if a man loves me?
Little things.
Little cares, little concerns.
How do I make the world know that it's good to be human, it's good to celebrate life and that prejudice is sinful?
Well, you write about a race riot in Magic City and you show people cross color lines, cross genders, coming together to make the world a better place.
And then Grandmother would tell me about Aunt Hattie who came back from the dead.
And that would...
Literally?
Well, there is a ritual.
Yes, I got to admit.
There is a ritual that grandmother told me about bringing spirits back from the dead.
And it's based on the belief in the African-American community that every goodbye ain't gone.
That the dead are always with you.
And I witnessed grandmother herself one day getting a phone call, right.
But the phone hadn't rung, but Grandmother got up out of bed, went down the stairs, picked up the telephone.
Said, yes?
Yes?
Then Grandmother came back upstairs, started getting dressed.
And Grandpa was going, woman, what's wrong with you?
And us kids, grandma, grandma.
It was like she was sleepwalking.
And then the phone rang, and it was a relative calling to tell us Aunt Hattie had died.
So the rest of us are barefoot in our pajamas, and what is Grandmother doing?
She's ready to walk out the door.
And she said, Aunt Hattie had called her.
And the thing about that is I would go down to the telephone, and I'd lift the receiver and I would expect the dead to call me.
But from that story, I learned that even though it's been 30 years, Grandma, I can still talk to you.
You know, she can come and talk to me when, you know, I need to have her grace.
So, yes, things like that happen.
They talk about magical realism, you know?
In the African-American community, it's not magical realism.
It's a fact of life.
The dead are still with us, and they are still accessible and you just need to call them.
I might have to put in a phone call to my own grandmother.
